text:
Generally, you could aim to increase your $/hour. There are many pathways to this.

Passive income approach that isn't an online course—build a niche content site/channel, get ad dollars or amazon referral dollars.

You could create assets vs "course" content, (eBooks, toolkits).

Some iceberg tips to consider!

elements.text:
Generally, you could aim to increase your $/hour. There are many pathways to this.

Passive income approach that isn't an online course—build a niche content site/channel, get ad dollars or amazon referral dollars.

You could create assets vs "course" content, (eBooks, toolkits).

Some iceberg tips to consider!

text: <@U02AR2XSN1M> You could also create a scaleable media product — a newsletter / podcast / etc. A ton of work at the start, but.... as you grow, your hours can remain the same while your audience (and $) grows.

elements.text: You could also create a scaleable media product — a newsletter / podcast / etc. A ton of work at the start, but.... as you grow, your hours can remain the same while your audience (and $) grows.

text: Have you heard of Ed Gandia? He's a copywriting business couch and one of his specialties is helping six-figure or near-six-figure copywriters take their business to the next level—whatever that looks like for them. For many, it's "work less or with better clients while maintaining my income or growing my income." I paid for a 9-month coaching course with him a couple of years ago and it was well worth the investment of time and money. At different benchmarks, you check in with him and report on what you're liking/not liking about your business and he provides personalized steps to follow. I really liked it and think it may help you tease out this question with other successful "freelancers."

text:
Thanks so much folks! Appreciate the tips. I probably sounded a bit negative but I feel a bit stuck in a rut at the moment. (Endless lockdown isn't helping either). <@U0241GTJEDC> I haven't heard of Ed; I'll check him out, thanks. I follow another lady who has a similar approach, Brook McCarthy, and have been eyeing off her coaching for a while.
<@U024A8928AW> &<@U01AHL8AGBB> - you're right, an asset could be worth thinking about - I have a lot of clients come to me and say 'can you just have a look at our site and tell us how it can be better' so I think there's a knowledge gap there somewhere with the old-school manufacturing businesses that I work with.
Thanks!

elements.text: Thanks so much folks! Appreciate the tips. I probably sounded a bit negative but I feel a bit stuck in a rut at the moment. (Endless lockdown isn't helping either).
I haven't heard of Ed; I'll check him out, thanks. I follow another lady who has a similar approach, Brook McCarthy, and have been eyeing off her coaching for a while.

- you're right, an asset could be worth thinking about - I have a lot of clients come to me and say 'can you just have a look at our site and tell us how it can be better' so I think there's a knowledge gap there somewhere with the old-school manufacturing businesses that I work with.
Thanks!

text: <@U02AR2XSN1M> Not negative at all! I think it's smart to be thinking of how to expand your income without having to put in (necessarily) more hours — otherwise there's always a cap. Let us know how it goes.

elements.text: Not negative at all! I think it's smart to be thinking of how to expand your income without having to put in (necessarily) more hours — otherwise there's always a cap. Let us know how it goes.

text:
<@U02AR2XSN1M>

> Just curious what others have done to increase their earning capacity past the ‘x hours in a day’ limit?
Check the book “Hourly billing is nuts” by Jonathan Stark

<https://jonathanstark.com/hbin>

Solid read. It helps folks get off the hamster wheel of selling hours for time.

Past that, I love _Productized Services_, where you switch to selling a fixed-price, fixed-scope, fixed-deliverable, fixed-timeline productized service. _(This is how my SEO X-Ray service works.)_

That way, you’re selling something you know you can deliver for a fixed price. As your processes improve, you’re making more per hour.

attachments.title: Hourly Billing Is Nuts by Jonathan Stark
attachments.text: “Every freelancer who bills hourly should be FORCED to read this book.” —Matt Inglot
attachments.fallback: Jonathan Stark: Hourly Billing Is Nuts by Jonathan Stark

text: That sounds cool thank you <@U01KH3P18RZ>. I have a few clients on retainer packages, but my two main clients are on hourly rate, and one is heavily micromanaging me... I'm keen to break away from them!
